qas.question: What is different about the use of Greek language today as opposed to the language of the past ?

answers.text: Modern Greek has, in addition to Standard Modern Greek or Dimotiki, a wide variety of dialects

qas.question: What are some of the local jargon used in Greek speaking?

answers.text: wide variety of dialects of varying levels of mutual intelligibility, including Cypriot, Pontic, Cappadocian, Griko and Tsakonian

qas.question: What language still survives as the representation of the one of the three religious orders of historic Greece ?

answers.text: Tsakonian (the only surviving representative of ancient Doric Greek)

qas.question: What ancient language is still in use today in some of the minuscule societies in the Grecian world ?

answers.text: Yevanic is the language of the Romaniotes, and survives in small communities in Greece, New York and Israel.

qas.question: Do the people of Greek ascendancy only speak Grecian languages ?

answers.text: bilingual in other languages or dialects such as English, Arvanitika/Albanian, Aromanian, Macedonian Slavic, Russian and Turkish.

qas.question: What is different about the use of Greek language today as opposed to the language of the future?

plausible_answers.text: Cypriot, Pontic, Cappadocian, Griko and Tsakonian

context: <a0_0>Modern Greek has, in addition to Standard Modern Greek or Dimotiki, <b5_0>a <a1_0>wide variety of dialects<b5_0/><a0_0/> of varying levels of mutual intelligibility, including <b6_0>Cypriot, Pontic, Cappadocian, Griko and <a2_0><b7_0>Tsakonian<b7_0/><b6_0/><a1_0/> (the only surviving representative of ancient Doric Greek)<a2_0/>. <a3_0><b8_0>Yevanic<b8_0/> is the language of the Romaniotes, and survives in small communities in Greece, New York and Israel.<a3_0/> In addition to Greek, many Greeks in Greece and the Diaspora are <a4_0><b9_0>bilingual in other languages<b9_0/> or dialects such as English, Arvanitika/Albanian, Aromanian, Macedonian Slavic, Russian and Turkish.
